captions.text:
the image
of the Nobel is...

I see. You came here
to find out if I was crazy?

screw everything up
if I actually won?

Dance around the podium,
strip naked and squawk
like a chicken,

but I still see things
that are not here.

I just choose
not to acknowledge them.
Like a diet of the mind,

I choose not to indulge
certain appetites.

Perhaps my appetite
to imagine and to dream.

It's good to have
<i>you here, John.

It's an honor, sir.
Thank you very much.

Nicely done, John.
Thank you, Tom.

Comparing a work of fiction - that blatantly plagiarized the work of 
another author - to a life story millions of people will be exposed to are 
two entirely different things. Especially as a person who advocates for the 
awareness of the mentally ill and disabled and against their stereotyping 
in media depictions. Secondly, the "verbatim" strawman never fails to 
appear in these kinds of discussions. It's kind of hilarious because in 
spite of the numerous liberties this film takes with the man's life 
story(including the portrayal of his marriage) I didn't hate the film. You 
of course, got butthurt over a sentence. Now THAT, was entertaining.
comments.author: Mwatuangi V

comments.text:
Who cares if it's fake. Do you think if they took your life and made a 
screenplay verbatim, regardless of the experiences that you've had in your 
life the accounts from life to screen would transcend to an emotional 
outbreak from the viewer. Doubted. "BASED ON A TRUE STORY".... the key word 
is BASED. You cannot take accounts from a historic event from years ago and 
make it to the T. Absorb the story for what it is. The scene was an 
emotional scene. Were you blown away from The Matrix? It was fake! It was 
CGI. But did you walk away thinking that it was fake and shout out on the 
"Internets". You walk away taking the emotion bestowed on you. Not that it 
was fake, but that it touched a part of your soul that the 
director\screenwriter\whoever wanted you to bestow. It's hollywood...... 
take it for what it is. If producers,writers, directors weren't using their 
creativity, then you'd be less entertained as Russell Crowe, or Maximums 
would say, " Are you not entertained?!" Think that actually happened? 
No...but were you not entertained?

Perhaps John Nash's insanity was a means to think outside the box. The 
movie portrays many crazy scenes--which makes insanity very 
dramatic--however once his insanity was put under control--his genius 
really propelled him to the world of fame. The mind is something we will 
never get a grasp on--maybe for good reason. To control the mind of genius 
limits the creativity the mind truly has. Insanity may be the only hope for 
mankind.
